frameDefinitions: This frame concerns a Cognizer's certainty about the correctness of beliefs  or expectations.
A Believer has faith in a piece of Content or an Element  which fits into a religious belief system made up of many articles of faith.
The existence of a State_of_affairs is sufficient reason for taking an Action .
In this frame, which is a  part of the Trial sequence, a Judge gives a Finding with respect to the Charges against the Defendant in a particular Case.
A Cognizer thinks that the Information given by a particular Source is correct.
A Cognizer holds a particular Opinion, which may be portrayed as being about a particular Topic.
frameExamples: Lermontov was <t>certain</t> he would come to the party.
Do Muslims <t>believe</t> in the virgin birth of Jesus?
The underwater sequences <t>warrant</t> the price of the admission alone.
He was <t>convicted</t> of fraud by Judge Judy.
John <t>thinks</t> that it looks better back .
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Cognizer</fen> is the person whose certainty or uncertainty is at issue.
The <fen>Topic</fen> is the entity that a <fen>Cognizer</fen> has a certain/uncertain belief about.
The <fen>Content</fen> denotes the mental content that the <fen>Cognizer</fen> is certain or uncertain about.
The <fen>Expressor</fen> is the body part or action by a body part that conveys the mental state of  the <fen>Cognizer</fen>.
The <fen>Believer</fen> is the person whose religious beliefs are in question.
The <fen>Content</fen> is the object of the <fen>Believer</fen>'s religious conviction. <fen>Content</fen> can be expressed as a finite clause or in a in-PP Complement.
<fen>Role</fen> is a  function that an Element of the faith is believed to serve.
A predefined, fixed idea to which reference is made throughout the belief system.
An Eventuality or an Entity that is taken to constitute sufficient reason for taking another <fen>Action</fen>.
An <fen>Action</fen> that is taken to be justifiable given the <fen>State_of_Affairs</fen>.
The <fen>Judge</fen> (which may be the jury, judge, magistrate or court) decides on the <fen>Finding</fen>.
This role identifies the outcome of the <fen>Judge</fen>'s deliberation or consideration. Many LUs in this frame incorporate this FE.
The person who stands accused of a crime and is subject to the verdict.
This role refers to the <fen>Charges</fen> with respect to which the verdict is being given.
The <fen>Case</fen> on which the verdict is being given.
When the event occurs.
Where the event takes place.
The <fen>Cognizer</fen> is the person who has an opinion about the reliability of a <fen>Information_source</fen> or the <fen>Information</fen> from the <fen>Information_source</fen>.
An object or action associated with the <fen>Cognizer</fen> which is so affected by the <fen>Cognizer</fen>'s belief that it reveals the <fen>Cognizer</fen>'s state.
The individual that gives Information to the <fen>Cognizer</fen>.
The text or speech which the <fen>Cognizer</fen> has heard and evaluates the truth of.
The <fen>Cognizer</fen> is the person whose <fen>Opinion</fen> is in question.
The <fen>Cognizer</fen>'s way of thinking, which is not necessarily generally accepted, and which is generally dependent on the <fen>Cognizer</fen>'s point of view.
The <fen>Time</fen> at which the <fen>Cognizer</fen> has the <fen>Opinion</fen>.
listRoleExamples: <fex>Marcel</fex> was sure that she had seen Eldridge on the balcony.
She talked of quests , of finding this absurd religious character , but he was unsure <fex>of her conviction</fex>.
I am sure <fex>that we'll arrive on time</fex>.
She caught sight of her mother's dubious <fex>expression</fex>.
A Christian believes <fex>that Jesus of Nazareth was a prophet</fex>.
If a person believes in Jesus <fex>as his Saviour</fex>, he can he baptized.
<fex>A heavy contact to the opponent 's face</fex> may not merit just a verbal warning
Her trustworthy <fex>eyes</fex> revealed that I was in no danger.
America trusted <fex>his declaration</fex> , to their detriment .
<fex>My</fex> take is that Johnson will not actually make it to the last round .

My take is <fex>that it is a version of the Macbeth story - what happens when people
become violent but cannot quite handle it</fex>.

passageCandidateSpans.text: Volume 100 of Fathers of the Church

sourceCandidateSpans.text: James the brother of the Lord"
James the Less and of Joseph
Vol. 2. New York: Robert Appleton Company
